items.label:
New Econometric Model of Evaluation by Sectoral Interdependency
and Supply
items.name:
New Econometric Model of Evaluation by Sectoral Interdependency
and Supply
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
NEMESIS is a multi-country macro-sectoral econometric model for EU27 (plus USA and Japan), which can be used for assessment of structural policies, mainly environmental and R&D policies. The main mechanisms of the model are based on the behaviour of representative agents: enterprises, households, government and outside.
The model is mainly used for:
Â assessment of short and medium-term consequences of energy and environmental (air pollution) policies, R&D, technology-related and economic policies on EU economies and on the state of the environment;
Â short and medium-term (2-8 years) forecasts at a macro and sectoral level;
Â forecasting baseline scenarios for 30 years' time, including sustainable development scenarios.
items.field_input: Data Source(s):  EUROSTAT, and specific databases for external trade (OECD, New CRONOS), technology (OECD and EPO) and land use (CORINE 2000).
items.field_output:
annual forecasts:
Â for the EU27 countries, USA and Japan;
Â for 32 production sectors and 27 consumption good categories;
Â for 6 types of air-borne emissions.

items.label: NEST
items.name: NEST
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: Water quality Impact Assessment for the Baltic Sea

items.label: N-Vino
items.name: N-Vino
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: N-Vino is a dynamic, process-based simulation model for viticulture, simulating water and nitrogen cycles in soil and crop and their combined impact on crop growth and yield. NVino calculates a large number of state variables on a daily basis using a handful of weather and site information. As an offspring of the HERMES model it was designed to work robustly under limited input information, supporting the user to understand the behaviour of certain variables in a vineyard under changing climate, site and management. Its main purpose is to assess organic fertiliser impact on yield and N leaching.

items.label: PACE (Policy Analysis based on Computable Equilibrium)
items.name: PACE (Policy Analysis based on Computable Equilibrium)
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
PACE is a flexible system of computable general equilibrium (CGE) models which integrates the areas of economy, energy, and environment. The generic core of PACE is a standard multi-sector, multi-region CGE framework of global trade and energy use designated to assess major policy initiatives in a world that is increasingly integrated through trade. Departing from the generic core, the various PACE modules allow for the problem-specific analysis of policy interference at different regional and sectoral levels as well as time treatments (static, dynamic-recursive, intertemporal). The different PACE modules account for issuedriven priorities in the representation of details and functional
relationships. There is a module that emphasizes discrete technological choice in the energy system thereby featuring a bottom-up representation of alternative electricity supply options. Another modules incorporate a detailed description of labour market imperfections and public taxation to trace back the interaction of tax policies and involuntary unemployment (e.g. due to union-bargaining). Further modules include a disaggregate representation of different household types or overlapping generations in order to allow for more detailed incidence analysis or a vintage approach to car stocks in order to investigate the implications of alternative emission regulation policies for automobile industries. More recently, an integrated assessment module has been added that links a reduced from representation of climate relationships with a comprehensive intertemporal multi-sector, multi-region model for the world economy.

items.label: PESTNAB
items.name: PESTNAB
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: Impacts of pesticides on the surrounding habitats.

items.label: PHOENIX latest version: PHOENIX plus
items.name: PHOENIX latest version: PHOENIX plus
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The PHOENIX model was created to provide analysis on long-term population development at various geographical aggregation levels (global, regional, national and grid cells). The different modules of the model cover 19 world regions and 224 countries, including the EU27 member states.
The model is mainly used for:
Â comparing different demographic scenarios;
Â analysis of changes in population size and structure with respect to socio-economic and environmental transitions;
Â fertility and mortality patterns.
The PHOENIX model provides a framework for analysis of population changes for the period 1950-2100 for 19 world regions and 224 countries.
The model is made up of three components:
Â demographic core;
Â fertility model;
Â mortality model.
Demographic developments are modelled dynamically (allowing outcomes in one year to influence results in future years), as the mixture of the underlying fertility and mortality trends, which in turn depend on the simulated environmental and socio-economic conditions.
items.field_input: fertility rates, mortality rates, net migration
items.field_output: data on demographic changes, demographic scenarios; changes in population size and structure with respect to socio-economic and environmental transitions; fertility and mortality patterns.
items.field_scientific_documentation: Hilderink, H. B. M. (2000) World population in transition: an integrated regional modelling framework, Thela Thesis/Rozenberg, Amsterdam. Hilderink, H.B.M., Population & Scenarios, Worlds to win? 2004, Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (RIVM-MNP): Bilthoven, the Netherlands. Hilderink, H.B.M., People in the Pixel: Towards grid-based population modelling. Sustainable Planning and Development, 2005. 1(1). Hilderink, H.B.M., People in the Pixel: grid-based population dynamics using PHOENIX, in Integrated modelling of global environmental change. An overview of IMAGE 2.4, A.F. Bouwman, T. Kram, and K. Klein Goldewijk, Editors. 2006, Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (MNP).

items.label: Prospective Outlook on Long-term Energy Systems
items.name: Prospective Outlook on Long-term Energy Systems
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The POLES model is a partial equilibrium model for the world energy system up to 2030. The model is constructed at a world level, with detailed treatment of several large countries. POLES connects international, regional and national sub-models. Each region is modelled using four modules: 1) final energy demand by sector; 2) new and renewable energy technologies; 3) the conventional energy and transformation system; and 4) primary energy supply.
The model is mainly used for:
Â running world energy scenarios (energy demand, supply, trade, prices) by world region;
Â inter-technology substitution over time;
Â simulation of CO2 emission constraints and emissions trading;
Â analysing the impact of technological change on emission baselines and constrained cases.
For each of the 40 world regions considered, the model has four main modules dealing with:
Â final energy demand by main sector;
Â new and renewable energy technologies;
Â the conventional energy and electricity transformation system;
Â fossil fuel supply
items.field_input: The energy-balance data for the POLES model are extracted from an international energy database, which also includes international macro-economic data, the structure of economic activity, deflators and exchange rates. Technico-economic data (energy prices, equipment rates, costs of energy technologies, etc.) are gathered both from international and national statistics.
items.field_output:
The POLES model provides detailed yearly energy forecasts up to 2030:
Â for 40 countries and world regions;
Â for 12 sectors;
Â for 12 renewable-energy technologies and 12 electricity-generation technologies

items.label: Porpoise
items.name: Porpoise
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: Porpoise behaviour and population dynamics impact assessment

items.label: PRIMES
items.name: PRIMES
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
PRIMES is a simulation model of the energy markets in the European Union. It simulates market equilibrium for energy supply and demand in the Member States by finding the equilibrium prices for 24 energy sources. The equilibrium is static (within each time period) but repeated in a time-forward path, with dynamic relationships. The model is highly disaggregated and has very differentiated technologies.
The model is mainly used for:
Â analysis of standard energy-policy issues: security of supply, strategy, costs etc;
Â analysis of environmental issues;
Â looking at the impact of technology standards, new technologies and renewable resources;
Â looking at energy efficiency, alternative fuels, trade and EU energy provision;
Â analysis of policy issues regarding electricity generation, gas distribution and refineries.

In summary, the characteristics of PRIMES are such that the model is:
Â elaborated at a European rather than at a national level, with the national economies being treated as regions of Europe;
Â focused on policy analysis of the energy sector;
Â a disaggregated energy model, with detailed treatment of the electricity-generation sector and energy technology choice;
Â modular, allowing for flexible treatment of different sectors.
items.field_input: The basic source of data for energy consumption by sector and fuel is Eurostat. Other sources include surveys of cogeneration operation and capacities and surveys on boilers. The MURE, IKARUS, ODYSSE databases and national sources are also used.

items.label: QUEST (latest version: QUEST III)
items.name: QUEST (latest version: QUEST III)
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
QUEST II is a dynamic macro-economic model of the world economy. It is designed to analyse the economies in the member states of the European Union and their interactions with the rest of the world, especially with the US and Japan. The focus of the model is on the transmission of the effects of shocks and economic policies, both on the domestic and the international economy.
The model is mainly used for:
Â simulating the effects of fiscal and monetary policy;
Â evaluating the European Commission structural policies (e.g. Structural Funds, Trans-Europe transport networks, Internal Market);
Â analysis of long-term issues (e.g. demographic changes);
Â analysis of short-term shocks (e.g. exchange rate shocks);
Â medium-term projections (over 5 years).
The model was primarily constructed to serve as a tool for policy simulation.
The main features of the model are:
Â EU14 (EU15 excluding Luxembourg) and the new member states (the ageing model contains the EU15, USA, Japan and the rest of the world, split into slow ageing and fast ageing);
Â 3 sectors and 2 consumption categories;
Â monopolistic competition;
Â forward-looking expectations;
Â exogenous technical progress.
QUEST II can be used either in the single-country version where the rest of the world is an aggregate of all other countries/regions or the multi-country version where individual countries are linked by endogenous (price-dependent) bilateral trade and financial flows.
items.field_contact:
Andre Dramais, andre.dramais@cec.eu.int
Werner Roeger, werner.roeger@cec.eu.int
items.field_input: AMECO, Eurostat for national accounts data

items.label: Resource and Energy Analysis Programme
items.name: Resource and Energy Analysis Programme
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
REAP provides scenario and modelling and policy assessment on the issue of Sustainable Consumption and Production.
Designed by the Stockholm Environment Institute and Centre for Urban and Regional Ecology, REAP uses some of the most sophisticated modelling approaches to understand the material flows, carbon dioxide emissions, greenhouse gas emissions and Ecological Footprint of the UK, regions and local authorities.
REAP is a database of all the footprint data in the UK,
updated as new data is released and also a highly
sophisticated model for policy and scenario analysis. Using the baseline data the tool provides the following functions (for all local authorities and regions in the UK):
Â Footprint data by production sector
Â Footprint by household consumption category
Â Time series emissions data from 1992-2004 by region
Â A comparison tool to compare data across geographies
Â A composite region function to join local authorities or regions
Â Update data function where baseline data can be changed
Â Future scenario creation and analysis
Â Evaluation of scenarios and results display
The data and scenario results can be extracted out of the database at any time, exported into Excel or Word. All results are available as per capita or total values.

items.label: REBECCA toolbox
items.name: REBECCA toolbox
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The specific aims of REBECCA are:
Â to describe current knowledge of relationships between ecological status of surface waters and both hydromorphological and physico-chemical quality elements as modified by pressures from different sources;
Â to identify knowledge gaps;
Â to develop new relationships based on the integrated
analysis of existing data sets at European scale;
Â to investigate synergistic or antagonistic effects of combined pressures;
Â to present a consistent and integrated scientific
understanding of these relationships; and
Â to develop and validate tools that member states can use in the process of classification, in the design of their monitoring programs, and in the design of measures in accordance with the requirements of the WFD.

items.label: RIVER BASIN MANAGER'S TOOLBOX
items.name: RIVER BASIN MANAGER'S TOOLBOX
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: River Basin Manager's Toolbox provides information and tools needed in the implementation of the Water Framework Directive (WFD) and will assist the River Basin managers in various steps of the WFD implementation process.

items.label: ROTOR
items.name: ROTOR
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: ROTOR, a static rule-based tool for planning site-specific and agronomically sustainable crop rotations for organic farming systems in central Europe. It consists of two basic steps: (A) A set of annual crop production activities (CPAs) assembled semi-automatically from single site and crop-specific field operations using a relational data base. (B) the crop generation module. Agronomically sustainable 3-8-year crop rotations are generated and selected according to exclusion criteria (i.e., thresholds for N balance, weed infestation risks, phytosanitary and chronological restrictions) using rulebased assessment modules. ROTOR is able to reduce the risk of planning failures by offering a quantitative method of optimisation of weed and site-specific N management

items.label: Spatial Analysis and Modelling Tool
items.name: Spatial Analysis and Modelling Tool
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
SAMT, the spatial analysis and modelling tool is a toolbox for model development and model integration. The focus of SAMT is the combination of modern soft computing methods, like fuzzy modelling, neural networks and support vector machines, with spatial simulations. The modeller can implement his models in SAMT due to a simple modelling interface. SAMT is build as a modelling framework and supports the modeller and the user of the models with powerful analysis techniques. As open source software SAMT
can be easily changed and adapted.

items.label: System for Environmental and Agricultural Modelling - Linking European Science and Society
items.name: System for Environmental and Agricultural Modelling - Linking European Science and Society
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
SEAMLESS-IF will facilitate translation of policy questions into alternative scenarios that can be assessed through a set of indicators that capture the key economic, environmental, social and institutional issues of the questions at stake. The indicators in turn are assessed using an intelligent linkage of quantitative models. These models have been designed to simulate aspects of agricultural systems at specific scales, i.e. point or field scale, farm, region, EU and world. Application of the models requires pan-European databases for environmental, economic and social issues. Some indicators, particularly social and institutional ones, will be assessed directly from data or via a post-model analysis.

The smooth linkage of models designed for different scales and from biophysical and economic domains requires software architecture, and a design and technical implementation of models that allows this. The software backbone of the project, SeamFrame, serves that purpose. SeamFrame is also developed to facilitate re-use, maintenance and documentation of models.
items.field_input: Environmental conditions, farm structural data, farm management, policies
items.field_output: Changes in farm and regional economics and environmental conditions for future policy and technological changes
items.field_scientific_documentation: http://www.seamless-ip.org/

items.label: Sustainability Impact Assessment Tools (SENSOR)
items.name: Sustainability Impact Assessment Tools (SENSOR)
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
SIAT is a meta model that allows the user to conduct
integrated analysis of global change and policy scenarios across the sectors agriculture, forestry, energy, transport infrastructure, nature conservation and tourism. Simulations for ex-ante impact assessment can be carried out for the
target year 2025 covering 574 European regions of the EU27.
Each simulation computes 87 indicators and nine Land Use Functions that illustrate the policy impact on social,
economic and environmental goods and services at a
national as well as regional level.
items.field_enduser_documentation: Documentation (Reference Handbook) is available on the prototype http://siat.cgi-systems.nl/SiatGUI/
items.field_output:
9 land use classes built-up land, permanent crops, irrigated arable land, arable land (non-irrigated), forest, pasture, natural vegetation, abandoned pasture land, abandoned arable land;
Income indicators for each region, unemployment and empoyment indicator separated by age and gender classes;
Nitrogen, phosphorus, balances and pesticide use at regional level;
Ammonia, Methan and N2O and NH3 emission from agricultural at regional level;
Fossile energy demand area in agriculture;
Â Green House Gas inventories for agriculture according to international standards (IPCC) at regional, national and EU level;
Â economic indicators (sectoral gross added value and deviation indicators)
Â soil indicators (erosion water, soil sealing, soil organic carbon content)
Â Forest fire risk
Â tourism indicators (Discharge urban waste tourism, Recreational tourism pressure, Social tourism pressure)
Â Carbon sequestration
Â Green House Gas inventories for agriculture according to international standards (IPCC) at regional, national and EU level;
Â Biodiversity indicators (deadwood, farmland birds)
Â Landscape indicators (lContinuity of appreciated landscape heritage, visual attractivity)
Â Water retention capacity
items.field_scientific_documentation: Scientific documenation is available on http://www.sensor-ip.eu/  and http://siat.cgi-systems.nl/SiatGUI/

items.label: Sustainable Metropolitan Regions
items.name: Sustainable Metropolitan Regions
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: The SUSMETRO Impact Assessment tool provides information on the expected effects of spatial planning with regard to the self-supportive capacities of the region (ecological footprint) and the share of recreational and nature conservation facilities (land use functions), offering cost-benefit calculations regarding the expected economic revenues. The whole process is embedded in a Landscape Character Assessment process and guided by Knowledge Brokerage procedures to strengthen the science-policy interface. Using the format of a 'serious game', stakeholders can choose between a mix of agriculture in which more intensive and more multifunctional agriculture both have a place. The SUSMETRO game is implemented in the Excel and ESRI ArcGIS software. The ArcGIS software is used to display maps, to draw sketches and to compute the areas of the current and the new Land Use Functions (LUF). The user-interface is a digital Maptable which allows users to directly draw on the screen and to immediately retrieve results of the impact assessments for each of their design proposals.
items.field_scientific_documentation:
Dirk M Wascher, Herman Agricola, Bas Breman and Barbara J. Anderson, 2009: Innovation Characteristics for
Sustainable Metropolitan Agriculture - Spatial-Functional Perspectives for TransForum Innovative Projects, SUSMETRO Project Report Phase 1, 59 pages;

items.label: Transactional Environmental Support System
items.name: Transactional Environmental Support System
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: TESS (Transactional Environmental Support System) is a decision support tool (under development) that aims at assisting policy makers to integrate knowledge from the EU, national, regional and local level into the decision making process. TESS will use geospatial data to generate information of immediate application by both short term planners of farming (e.g. area J of crop K should produce ÂL-M next year based on estimates of demand, supply and weather) as well as long term policy makers and planners (e.g. probability of extinction of species O in region P will increase through habitat-loss to bio-fuels if subsidy ÂQ is continued). In summary, TESS will facilitate the gathering and use of biodiversity and environmental information in Strategic Environmental Assessments and Sustainability Impact Assessments, and examine how the use of such information affects ecosystem services and biodiversity in both protected and cultivated areas.
items.field_enduser_documentation: Currently being developed - expected to be launched online in September 2011.
items.field_input: GIS data and maps, variables on local management of biodiversity, economic variables
items.field_output: Decision support
items.field_scientific_documentation: Kenward et al: Identifying governance strategies that effectively support ecosystem services, resource sustainability, and biodiversity. PNAS March 29, 2011 vol. 108 no. 13 5308-5312.

items.label: TOOLS for TRansport Forecasting ANd Scenario testing
items.name: TOOLS for TRansport Forecasting ANd Scenario testing
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The Trans-Tools Model is a European wide computer-aided transport-planning tool. The model aims to produce a European transport-network model covering both passengers and freight with interactions to an economic model and impacts models. The model supports transport policy makers in two ways. First, to monitor trends in the operation of the transport system in the EU and to identify issues for which policy intervention may be required. Second, to assess the impact of specific transport-policy measures on the transport system in the EU, as well as on selected economic end environmental issues.

The model is based on flexible software adoptable to user needs which is IPR (intellectual property right) free.

The model is mainly used for:
Â analysis of construction and improvement of transport infrastructure;
Â analysis of implementation of infrastructure charging systems;
Â analysis of charge of transport costs due to policy interventions, increases in fuel prices, etc.

The model covers passenger transport at NUTS-III level in EU25+2, using recently updated networks. Data from other recent projects, like ETIS-BASE, are also used.

items.label: TREMOVE
items.name: TREMOVE
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
TREMOVE is a policy assessment model, designed to study the effects of different transport and environment policies and technologies on the emissions of the transport sector. The model covers both passenger and freight transport, annually over 1995-2030. The model estimates the transport demand, the modal split, the vehicle stock turnover, the emissions of
air pollutants and the welfare level under different policy scenarios.
TREMOVE is made up of a land-transport model and a maritime model. The land-transport section has been set up to model all transport within a selected country. Currently there are 31 countries in the input databases.
The model is mainly used for:
Â simulating the effects of various types of individual or combined transport-policy measures on transport flows, on the size and composition of the vehicle stock, vehicle usage and on emissions.

items.label: VACLAV
items.name: VACLAV
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
VACLAV is a network-based Europe-wide passenger transport forecasting model. The model is mainly used for:
Â forecasting network demand and traffic loads;
Â determining regional indicators, such as access by mode of transport, based on changes in network capacities and capacity constraints;
Â modelling freight transport.
The main features of the model are:
Â 4-step approach: trip generation, trip distribution, mode choice, route choice/assignment;
Â representation of physical road and rail networks, airports, ferries;
Â 100,000 road network links and 5,000 rail network links.
In summary, the characteristics of VACLAV are such that the model is:
Â constructed at the European level;
Â based on the classic 4-step transport model approach;
Â reliant on current transport infrastructure and planned investments.

items.label: Very Simple Dynamic Model
items.name: Very Simple Dynamic Model
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
A model that is specifically developed for application at the European scale is VSD+ . This models allows to calculate impacts of (i) air quality parameters, including exposure to NH3 and NOx and deposition of N and acidity and (ii) climatic parameters related to water availability and temperature on ecosystem services including:
Â Carbon sequestration in wood and soil (climate regulating service).
Â Water/soil quality by its impact on acidity (pH) and on soil accumulation and leaching of nitrogen, aluminium and metals to ground water and surface water (regulating service, i.e. clean soil and water).
The model can also calculate critical loads and target loads for nitrogen and acidity and is under development to predict the diversity of plant species by its impact on the habitat function for wild plants (provisioning service).
items.field_enduser_documentation: Posch, M., Reinds, G.J., 2005. VSD - User Manual of the Very Simple Dynamic soil acidification model. Coordination Center for Effects, National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), Bilthoven, The Netherlands.
items.field_scientific_documentation: Posch, M., Reinds, G.J., 2009. A very simple dynamic soil acidification model for scenario analyses and target load calculations. Environmental Modelling and Software 24, 329-340

items.label: Water - a Global Assessment and Prognosis
items.name: Water - a Global Assessment and Prognosis
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
WaterGAP is an integrated-environmental model, combining socio-economic drivers and climate change in a single, integrated framework.
It was developed to model water availability, use and quality on a global level. WaterGAP comprises of a hydrological module, used in determining global water resources and water availability, and a water-use module, which looks at consumption from different economic sectors, including a sub-model for an assessment of global irrigation requirements.
The model is mainly used for:
Â assessing the impact of global developments (e.g. climate change on water availability and water demand;
Â determining different water-stress conditions of different regions.
items.field_input:
Global map of irrigation areas: Contains information about the area of each 0.5 degree cell (area 9.25 km by 9.25 km at the equator) that was equipped for irrigation around 2000. The dataset was developed by the Centre of Environmental Systems Research, Kassel University in 1999 and updated with the help of the Land and Water Development Division of the Food Organisation of the United Nations in 2007.  

Global drainage direction map: The dataset describes the drainage direction of surface water, under the form of a map (spatial resolution of 30Â longitude by 30Â latitude). 

Global lakes, wetlands and reservoir dataset.
items.field_output: impacts of global change on water availability and water demand, and to determine the development of water stress conditions on different spatial and temporal scales.

items.label: Decision support system for decision making in regional planning, sustainable development of agricultural regions and environmental protection
items.name: Decision support system for decision making in regional planning, sustainable development of agricultural regions and environmental protection
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: A Decision support system (Watermap-DSS) for decision making in regional planning, sustainable development of agricultural regions and environmental protection. The DSS evaluates alternative plans and the effects of different policies. The DSS developed in the framework of Interreg - Archimed project entitled 'WATERMAP - Development and utilization of vulnerability maps for the monitoring and management of groundwater resources in the Archimed area' (2006/2008). Its aim is to optimize the production plan of an agricultural region taking in account the available resources, environmental parameters and the vulnerability map of the region. The DSS is based on an optimization multicriteria model. The spatial integration of the vulnerability maps in the DSS enables the regional authorities to design and assess policies for the optimal agricultural development and the groundwater protection from the agricultural land uses. The DSS is also used to simulate different scenarios and policies by the local stakeholders, due to changes on different social, economic and environmental parameters.
items.field_enduser_documentation: Basil Manos, Jason Papathanasiou, Thomas Bournaris. Â«Best Practice Guide, DSS guideÂ» (2008)
items.field_input: land, labour, capital, technical and economica data
items.field_output: groundwater maps, environmental indicators
items.field_scientific_documentation: B. Manos, J. Papathanasiou, Th. Bournaris and K. Voudouris, ÂA DSS for Sustainable Development and Environmental Protection of Agricultural RegionsÂ, Environmental Monitoring and Assessment (2010) Volume 164, Numbers 1-4, pp. 43Â52

items.label: Watersketch Toolbox
items.name: Watersketch Toolbox
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The Watersketch Toolbox informs the user about basic
principles in river basin management, and describes how the quality of watercourses can be affected by different human actions. Also, information for setting up the environmental objectives, as well as of measures needed for achieving them, is offered. Finally, the open and transparent planning process is promoted by giving hints and ideas of different participatory planning methods. Several practical tools developed for assisting planners and authorities in different phases of the planning process are presented in the Watersketch Toolbox. In addition to user instructions, a wide set of real-life tool applications can be found. Tools in the Watersketch Toolbox:

- RiverLifeGIS - a software for hydrological and water quality computations on river catchments using geographical information (GI) and monitored water quality data;
- Web-HIPRE - a tool for multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) using value-tree structure;
- Public Hearing Database - a tool for managing contributions from the public in any kind of spatial planning processes, also in river basin planning;
- Priority Game Generator - a tool for generating priority games, which offer citizens the possibility to attempt for themselves the often difficult act of balancing various interests against each other via the internet;
- REGCEL - tool for assessment of the ecological impacts of changes in water level fluctuation in lakes ;
- DHRAM - tool for assessment of the harmful impacts of flow changes in rivers

items.label: World Agricultural Trade SImulation Model
items.name: World Agricultural Trade SImulation Model
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
WATSIM is world trade model for agricultural commodities. It currently covers twelve regions, including the EU, and 29 commodities. The model integrates different types of trade policies, such as tariffs and quotas, safeguards and export subsidies.
The model is mainly used for:
Â medium-term analysis of trade policy changes;
Â analysing trends of agricultural world markets.
The model focuses on the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the European Union. The EU trade policies covered by WATSIM are: intervention price systems and export subsidies, WTO-limits on export subsidies, quotas on sugar and milk production and tariff-rate quotas for imports.
In the model all non-agricultural trade variables, such as capital, labour and GDP are assumed to be exogenous.
The main features of the model are:
Â annual dynamic solutions with developments in one year influencing outcomes in later years;
Â a focus on trade flows between regions.
Elasticities in the behavioural functions of the model are not estimated, but are calculated exogenously using other sources.
In summary, the main characteristics of WATSIM are such that the model is:
Â a trade-flow model of agricultural produce;
Â focused on trade-policy analysis;
Â designed for analysis in the European Union;
Â a partial-equilibrium model.

items.label: WITCH
items.name: WITCH
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
WITCH is a Regional Integrated Assessment Hard-Link Hybrid Model. Its top down component consists of an intertemporal optimal growth model in which the energy input of the aggregate production function has been expanded to give a bottom-up like description of the energy sector. World countries are grouped in twelve regions that strategically interact following a game theoretic structure. A climate module and a damage function provide the feedback on the economy of carbon dioxide emissions into the atmosphere. The model is structured so as to provide normative information on the optimal responses of world economies to climate damages and to model the channels of transmission of climate policy to the economic system. The dynamic and strategic features of the model, the energy sector specification and the technical change options make WITCH an especially suited tool to explicitly analyze the climate change issue, marked by medium term investment choices
and long term economic dynamics and environmental responses.

items.label: World Water Game
items.name: World Water Game
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: The WWG is a computer game with a double purpose. One, to be played as a game in the spirit of challenge, tension and fun. Two, to show students and other non-professionals the relationship between four extremely important elements: population growth; water supply (and use); food demand and production; and measures taken and investments made to avoid hunger, and even starvation, situations in the coming century.
items.field_input:
population growth
supply of water to irrigated agriculture
 irrigation efficiency
rainfed agriculture yield
items.field_output:
population: the number of inhabitants
food: discrepancy between food supply and demand
water: degree of exploitation of the regionÂs available water resources
investments: amount of money spent on measures

items.label: WorldScan
items.name: WorldScan
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
WorldScan is a recursive dynamic general equilibrium model to explore and analyse long-term issues in the world economy. The model is used as a tool to construct long-term scenarios and as an instrument for policy-impact assessment. WorldScan fits into the tradition of applied general equilibrium models in that it builds upon neoclassical theory, has strong micro-foundations and explicitly determines simultaneous equilibrium on a large number of markets. The model is solved as an equation system and thus is cast in a Computable General Equilibrium (CGE) format.
Dedicated versions of WorldScan exist and they are extensions of a core version in separate directions. These extensions are:
Â a climate-change version;
Â an energy version;
Â a version with R&D spillovers;
Â a version with imperfect competition

items.label: XPLORER
items.name: XPLORER
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The XPLORER is a web based online information platform for users interested in processes of peri-urbanisation and respective relation to sustainable development. Linked to a web-based data management system and a GEO-portal, the XPLORER provides information to processes, problems and places of peri-urbanisation in Europe and its regions. It supports planning and policy discussions on rural-urban land
use interactions at European and at regional level. Targeted user groups include planners, policy makers, stakeholders, practitioners, scholars and researchers dealing with ruralurban interactions and sustainable peri-urban development. The Xplorer was developed in the FP6 research project PLUREL (www.plurel-ip.eu) and features all results developed therein

items.label: YKR - Monitoring system of spatial structure
items.name: YKR - Monitoring system of spatial structure
items.author: user/0
items.field_body: Tool which is applicable for long term monitoring of spatial structure, regional and urban research, operational planning and impact assessment. Contains data on population, workforce, buildings (area and purpose of use), housing, car ownership, commuting and free-time housing in 250 m grid cells from 1980 onwards. Public and commercial services (e.g. shops) on coordinate level. Roads in vector format. Several analytical tools are built on the database. Can be used e.g. for analyzing trends, predicting future development, impact assessment.

items.label: SAFIRA II Megasite Management Toolsuite
items.name: SAFIRA II Megasite Management Toolsuite
items.author: user/0
items.field_body:
The Megasite Management Toolsuite MMT is a software tool for consultants, authorities and investors involved in the planning and assessment of revitalisation options for brownfields.
An impartially integrated assessment of possible alternatives for redeveloping a brownfield shall help to design sustainable and economically attractive reuse-options. MMT results shall facilitate a common approach and agreement among all stakeholders.
